bioghist.p: Marshall Clagett (1916-2005) was one of the world's leading historians of medieval science, in particular the work and influence of Archimedes. He received his bachelor's and master's degrees from George Washington University, and his Ph.D. in history from Columbia University. From 1947 to 1964, he was a professor of the History of Science and later Vilas Research Professor at the University of Wisconsin, where he also directed the Institute for Research in the Humanities for six years. From Wisconsin, he went to the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, where he was a professor in the School of Historical Studies. He was the author of more than a dozen volumes on the history of science and mathematics. His major work was the five-volume Archimedes in the Middle Ages, published over 20 years starting in 1964. His more recent scholarship focused on science in ancient Egypt. He was a fellow of the Medieval Academy of America, past president of the History of Science Society, and a member and former vice president of the American Philosophical Society.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of Marshall Clagett. Materials include: incoming and outgoing correspondence with colleagues and publishers; research notes, including photostats, photographs, and transcriptions of source material; articles and reprints; drafts of Clagett's manuscripts; course handouts; and correspondence and minutes from various professional organizations and societies, including the American Philosophical Society and the History of Science Society. The collection includes a small number of personal papers, including correspondence regarding Clagett's academic appointments and housing arrangements and a few receipts.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
